newsitem.title: GERMANY: German cocoa grind partly reflects plant shifts.
newsitem.headline: German cocoa grind partly reflects plant shifts.

text.p: German cocoa traders said a 21.2 percent fall in fourth quarter 1996 bean grindings was partly the result of shifts of processing capacity at the Hamester group between Berlin and Hamburg.
"I have heard capacity shifts have not run as smoothly as expected but the production losses should be temporary," one said.
"The German grind figure is not overly crucial to the market and might be offset by the higher Dutch figure and what many believe will be a good British result," he added.
But traders said the figure was surprisingly low -- after analysts forecast a two percent decline.
The confectionery industry association BDS put the fourth quarter 1996 grind at 56,254.7 tonnes after 71,375.0 tonnes in the same 1995 period.
The full year 1996 figure stands at 251,069.4 tonnes, down three percent from 1995.
BDS managing director Karsten Keunecke cited possible changes in European bean import flows but would not comment further on the discrepancy between the forecast and the result.
"All companies have put in their reports and this is the final figure," he said.
Traders said operators across Europe were shifting capacity across borders and there was also a lot of talk about plans by international groups to boost processing at origin.
"We have to start looking at pan-European chocolate consumption and become less focused on national grind results because they no longer tell the whole story," one said.
Physical cocoa markets here were subdued because of lacking fundamentals news and as manufacturers shied away from higher mark prices as a result of a firm sterling/mark ratio.
First quarter cif Ivorian bean prices were unchanged from levels before the Christmas and New Year holidays at 2.26 marks per kg, but buyers' price ideas were around 2.20.
The cocoa butter ratio was also unchanged at 2.68, with implied prices ex-works at 6.21 marks per kg versus 6.32 marks before the year-end break, with buyers at 6.10 marks.
